docs.lead_paragraph: FIRST, a disclosure: Dr. Terry Marx, New York City's first chief physician for school health, was more than a little reluctant to report for duty this week. Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy, her friend and former neighbor on the Upper West Side, cajoled her into accepting the job, supervising and trying to improve the scattershot health care programs offered in the city's 1,100 public schools.

headline.main: A School Pediatrician With a Lot of Clout

docs.abstract: Public Lives column profiles career of Dr Terry Marx; she discusses her role as supervisor of health care programs offered in New York City's public schools; photo (M)
docs.snippet: FIRST, a disclosure: Dr. Terry Marx, New York City's first chief physician for school health, was more than a little reluctant to report for duty this week.    Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy, her friend and former neighbor on the Upper West Side,...
docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Jon S. Corzine, a liberal Democrat who made a fortune as a Wall Street executive and spent about $60 million of it on his first campaign for public office, won election to New Jersey's open seat in the United States Senate yesterday after shattering the national spending record for a statewide race. Mr. Corzine fended off a determined but poorly financed challenge from Representative Bob Franks by outspending him 10 to 1, unleashing a nine-week barrage of television advertisements and an army of political foot soldiers who searched out votes in inner-city housing complexes and sprawling subdivisions across the state.

headline.main: Corzine Wins Costly Bid for Senate in New Jersey

docs.abstract: Liberal Democrat Jon S Corzine, former Goldman Sachs & Co co-chairman who spent record $60 million on his first campaign for public office, wins US Senate seat from New Jersey over Republican Repr Bob Franks; fends off determined but poorly financed challenge, outspending Franks 10 to 1; receives approximately 50 percent of popular vote, compared with approximately 47 percent for Franks; thanks voters; says victory is one of greatest thrills of his life; pledges to dedicate service in Senate to ensuring that everyone has same opportunity for American promise that he had; will succeed retiring Democrat Sen Frank R Lautenberg; Franks praises Corzine as good and decent man in concession speech, but says what he gained over course of 14-month campaign $60 million will never be able to buy; Corzine's quest for seat and some highlights of campaign discussed; maps; tally (M)
